In "Twilight of the Idols", Friedrich Nietzsche discusses Plato's idea that writing would lead to forgetfulness and argues that it has had the opposite effect. Nietzsche argues that writing has actually created a culture of memory that is stronger than ever before, and that it has allowed people to store, preserve, and transmit knowledge and ideas in a way that was not possible in an oral culture.

Nietzsche sees writing as a tool for preserving and strengthening the human memory, rather than a cause of forgetfulness. He argues that writing has allowed people to expand their capacity for recall, to preserve the memories and knowledge of their ancestors, and to transmit their own memories and knowledge to future generations.

In "Twilight of the Idols", Nietzsche also argues that the spread of literacy and the development of written culture has allowed for the creation of a vast library of knowledge, which he calls the "book memory". He sees this as a major factor in the development of modern civilization and argues that it has allowed people to access and build upon the knowledge of the past in ways that were not possible in an oral culture.

Overall, Nietzsche's view of writing as a tool for preserving and strengthening the human memory offers a counterargument to Plato's critique of writing, and provides a more positive perspective on the impact of writing on human culture and thought.
